Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of nutrient transport from plants to biotrophic pathogens
Award.AbstractNarration:
Diseases caused by plant pathogens are a perennial threat to global food security and cost hundreds of billions of dollars annually. The most cost-effective, sustainable method for disease control is to breed crops with naturally occurring plant genes for resistance to pathogens, which, in practice, are often quickly overcome by co-evolving pathogens. This project will lay the groundwork for a new approach to engineer genetic resistance, based on the fact that most pathogens depend on the plant host to supply essential nutrients for their growth. By identifying and engineering the plant genes responsible for nutrient transfer so that they can no longer be used by the pathogen, it could be possible to cut the pathogen's supply lines and prevent disease development. This approach could provide resistance against a wide range of pathogens and would be very difficult for pathogens to overcome by co-evolution.

This project focuses on plant-encoded transporters of amino acids and sugar that are co-opted by Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis (Hpa) to facilitate nutrient acquisition. This project will provide new insights into the contributions of host genes to pathogen nutrition, and will investigate mechanisms through which transporters are co-opted to serve the invader. These aspects of plant-pathogen interactions are critically important but inadequately understood and under-studied. Reverse genetics will be used to identify amino acid transporters necessary for colonization of Arabidopsis by Hpa. Double mutants and RNAi lines will be used to assess genetic redundancy and physiological compensation. Mutants will be studied to determine the impact on infection by other pathogens, and whether the associated phenotypes are due to perturbation of innate immune responses. A subset of transporters will be examined at the molecular level to evaluate the importance of their differential expression and subcellular localization for pathogen nutrient acquisition. Biochemical properties and effects of amino acid transporters on flux across the plasma membrane will be determined to identify their role in the plant. Finally, a novel approach combining metabolomics and labeled nutrients will be used to test the importance of amino acid transporters for pathogen nutrition. Project participants will engage in outreach through the Partnership for Research and Education in Plants, in which high school students will conduct original research on transporter mutants. Participating scientists benefit by honing their ability to discuss the global impact of plant science research and the specific significance of their projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant pathogens are a perennial threat to global food security. Currently, the most cost-effective, sustainable method for disease control is to breed crops with genes for resistance to pathogens. Naturally occurring resistance genes are bred into crops, but most of the time, they are quickly overcome by co-evolving pathogens. This project is aimed at finding an alternative way to develop crops bearing resistance to pathogens that would be more durable. Our approach exploits the fact that pathogens depend on the plant host to supply essential nutrients for their growth. The major goal of this project is to identify plant genes that are needed by the pathogen to extract nutrients from the plant. This fundamental research will set the stage for engineering the activity of these genes such that the pathogen would have limited access to essential nutrients (sugars, amino acids, etc…), and would not develop, thereby suppressing or diminishing disease. In principle, this approach will provide resistance against a wide range of pathogens and would be very difficult for pathogens to overcome by co-evolution.

One of the major difficulty in finding the plant genes important for pathogen feeding is identifying the genes active in the cells that are in contact with the pathogen, which represent only a small fraction of the cells of a leaf for instance. We thus developed a key tool to gain access to the genes active in these cells. This technique involved purifying the ribosomes and the associated mRNAs only from plant cells in contact with the pathogen. We used the oomycete Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis and its plant host Arabidopsis thaliana as a model system to develop this technique. We were successful in creating DNA fusions that enabled visualization of the cells infected by the pathogen and at the same time analysis of genes expressed in these cells. The analysis of the obtained data is currently in progress, and we expect to identify novel plant nutrient transport genes that can be exploited as described in the preceeding paragraph.

In parallel, we hypothesized that transfer of amino acids from the plant to the pathogen would be mediated by proteins called amino acid transporters. We studied the growth of the pathogen on plants in which the activity of several amino acid transporters that we suspected being involved in pathogen feeding had been suppressed. Our results showed that pathogen’s growth is altered on the mutant plants, but also that this effect could result from broader effects of the suppression of the activity of the amino acid transporter genes on the plant metabolism. The outcomes suggest that this approach for engineering pathogen resistance is promising but will require more work to sort out direct from indirect effects.

We disseminated our results in scientific publications and at local and international conferences. In addition, we collaborated with high school students from Virginia to perform experiments with mutant plants altered in amino acid transport. The student were asked to choose conditions to grow the plants in the classroom, gathered data on plant fitness, appearance, size, etc… and analyzed the data to draw conclusion on the effect of the mutations on plant development. The graduate students and faculty involved in the project met several times during a semester with the high school students to assess progress and help with the analyses.
